key_points: Scores of Afghan dual nationals, including Americans and citizens of other Western countries, have left Kabul via a newly reopened airport.
U.S. Special Representative Zalmay Khalilzad pressed the Taliban to allow the departures.
National Security Council spokesperson Emily Horne stated the U.S. facilitated the departure of its citizens and lawful permanent residents.
The Taliban were cooperative in facilitating the departures, showing flexibility and professionalism.
Qatari and Taliban officials announced Kabul airport is nearly fully operational after repairs.
Qatari special envoy Mutlaq al-Qahtani emphasizes transition from 'evacuation' to normal travel for those with valid documents.
Planes in Mazar-e Sharif meant to evacuate at-risk Afghans have been unable to leave due to Taliban restrictions and technical issues.
Recent Taliban actions include announcing an interim government, cracking down on protests, and requestioning the U.S.'s blacklist of their new interim interior minister.
International reactions vary, with concerns over Taliban's promises on government formation and treatment of protesters and journalists.
Former Afghan President Ashraf Ghani, who fled the country, denies fleeing with millions and is open to a U.N. investigation.
